Content: Students observe a worm creeping along the edge of a sidewalk at a very slow pace. One student claims that movement in multicellular organisms requires the interaction of body systems. Explain this claim.
Complete the sentences by choosing the correct answer from each box.
Nervous tissues :DD-1: different parts of the body. As a result, muscular tissues :DD-2: , causing the worm to move.

Key.Rationale: The nervous system, which consists of nerve cells, is responsible for coordinating all the actions of an organism by sending signals to all its body systems, including the muscular system.
The nervous system, which consists of nerve cells, is responsible for coordinating all the actions of an organism by sending signals to all its body systems, including the muscular system.

Content: Based on Figure 1, what is the probability of Individual E being able to taste the bitter chemical?

Key.Rationale: Based on the genotypes of Individuals A and B, Individual D will have the Tt genotype. Therefore, both parents of Individual E will have the Tt genotype. This means that Individual E has a three of four chance of inheriting at least one T allele, which would cause Individual E to have the bitter-taste trait.

Content: Figure 2 shows whether the members of a second family are able to taste the bitter chemical. Which family members are definitely heterozygous1 for the ability to taste the bitter chemical?
problems/NJG8S/media/3a.jpg
Select ùó¶ùóúùó´ of the eight options.

A.Choice: Individual I-1

Key.Rationale: The ability to taste the bitter chemical is a dominant trait, so non-tasters must inherit two copies of the non-tasting allele from their parents. This individual is a taster who has at least one child who is a non-taster. That means this individual must carry a copy of the recessive allele that they passed on to their children.

B.Choice: Individual I-2

Key.Rationale: The ability to taste the bitter chemical is a dominant trait, so non-tasters must inherit two copies of the non-tasting allele from their parents. This individual is a taster who has at least one child who is a non-taster. That means this individual must carry a copy of the recessive allele that they passed on to their children.

C.Choice: Individual II-1

D.Choice: Individual II-3

Key.Rationale: The ability to taste the bitter chemical is a dominant trait, so non-tasters must inherit two copies of the non-tasting allele from their parents. This individual is a taster who has at least one child who is a non-taster. That means this individual must carry a copy of the recessive allele that they passed on to their children.

The ability to taste the bitter chemical is a dominant trait, so non-tasters must inherit two copies of the non-tasting allele from their parents. This individual is a taster who has one parent who is a non-taster. That means that this individual must have inherited a copy of the recessive non-tasting allele from the non-taster parent.

The ability to taste the bitter chemical is a dominant trait, so non-tasters must inherit two copies of the non-tasting allele from their parents. This individual is a taster who has one parent who is a non-taster. That means that this individual must have inherited a copy of the recessive non-tasting allele from the non-taster parent.

Content: A student writes an explanation about the bitter-taste alleles and proteins found in the individuals represented in Figure 1. However, the student makes a couple of mistakes. Which statements contain the student's mistakes?
Select ùóßùó™ùó¢ of the six statements.

A.Choice: Individual A and Individual B each have only one copy of the bitter-taste gene.

Key.Rationale: Individuals A and B each have two copies of the bitter-taste gene: Individual A has two copies of the tasting allele, and Individual B has two copies of the non-tasting allele.

B.Choice: Individual A and Individual B each make only one form of the protein encoded by the bitter-taste gene.

C.Choice: Because Individual A and Individual B make different forms of the protein, one of them tastes the bitter chemical and the other does not.

D.Choice: However, Individual C has a different allele for the bitter-taste gene on each chromosome.

E.Choice: This causes Individual C's body to make two different forms of the bitter- taste protein.

F.Choice: The protein made from the t allele is what causes Individual C to taste the bitter chemical.

Key.Rationale: Individual C is able to taste the bitter chemical because of the dominant T allele.

Content: Figure 2 shows the rock layers and fossils in a second outcropping.
problems/NJG8S/media/5a.jpg
Explain the similarities and differences you see in the samples.
Complete the sentences by choosing the correct answer from each box.
Layer :DD-1: and Layer :DD-2: are the same age. Each layer contains the same type of :DD-3: because they formed during :DD-4: time periods.

Key.Rationale: The rock strata show that Layer D and Layer J have similar soil and fossils from the same types of organisms, which indicates that they formed during similar time periods.
The rock strata show that Layer D and Layer J have similar soil and fossils from the same types of organisms, which indicates that they formed during similar time periods.
The rock strata show that Layer D and Layer J have similar soil and fossils from the same types of organisms, which indicates that they formed during similar time periods.
Layers formed during different time periods show more significant soil differences and fossils from different organisms.
Layers formed during different time periods show more significant soil differences and fossils from different organisms.
The rock strata show that Layer D and Layer J have similar soil and fossils from the same types of organisms, which indicates that they formed during similar time periods.

Content: For each of the rock layers from Figure 1 that are listed, determine whether the evidence shows that the land was covered by water during its formation, whether the evidence shows that the land was exposed to air during its formation, or whether there is not enough evidence to support either claim.

A:Layer B.Choice: 2:Supports that the land was exposed to air

Key.Rationale: The presence of terrestrial animal fossils in Layer B supports the presence of an atmosphere during formation.

B:Layer C.Choice: 3:Not enough evidence to support either claim

Key.Rationale: The formation of Layer C is inconclusive because of a lack of fossils.

C:Layer D.Choice: 2:Supports that the land was exposed to air

Key.Rationale: The presence of fossilized feathers in Layer D supports an environment exposed to air.

D:Layer E.Choice: 1:Supports that the land was covered by water

Key.Rationale: Fossils of aquatic dwellers in Layer E support the presence of an aquatic environment.

Content: Which list correctly arranges the given rock layers from the oldest layer to the youngest layer?

A.Choice: Layer B (oldest) ‚Üí Layer D ‚Üí Layer E ‚Üí Layer G (youngest)

B.Choice: Layer G (oldest) ‚Üí Layer D ‚Üí Layer E ‚Üí Layer B (youngest)

C.Choice: Layer B (oldest) ‚Üí Layer E ‚Üí Layer D ‚Üí Layer G (youngest)

D.Choice: Layer G (oldest) ‚Üí Layer E ‚Üí Layer D ‚Üí Layer B (youngest)

Key.Rationale: The law of superposition can be used to classify the relative ages of layers in this undisturbed section of rock. Because they were created first, older layers are located below younger layers. Of the layers listed, Layer B is the youngest and Layer G is the oldest because of their positions.

Content: A student claims that onions are not living things. The student places a small section of onion root on a microscope slide to view it at a larger magnification. Using the microscope, the student is able to see details of the onion root that are not visible to the naked eye as shown in Figure 1.
problems/NJG8S/media/8a.jpg
Based on the microscope slide, which statements disprove the student's claim?
Select ùóßùó™ùó¢ of the five statements.

A.Choice: Onion cells use energy.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because this characteristic is not verifiable in the microscope slide.

B.Choice: Onions respond to stimuli.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because this characteristic is not verifiable in the microscope slide.

C.Choice: Onion roots are made up of cells.

Key.Rationale: The onion root under a microscope clearly shows that is it made up of many cells. All living things have this trait and it can be detected on the microscope slide.

D.Choice: Onions engage in movement.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because this characteristic is not verifiable in the microscope slide.

E.Choice: Onion cells are able to reproduce.

Key.Rationale: The onion root under a microscope clearly shows many of its cells in various stages of reproduction. All living things have this trait and it can be detected on the microscope slide.

Content: Based on the investigation, the student group decides to add a large number of earthworms to their flower garden. Which statement ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß explains whether these data are being applied correctly?

A.Choice: The garden is a less stable system, and the results can be easily duplicated.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because although the garden is likely a less stable system, the two systems (potted plants vs. garden) have different variables. The fact that the garden is a less stable system is a major difference.

B.Choice: The garden is a more stable system, and the results cannot be easily duplicated.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because a system's stability does not prevent changes from taking hold in the system, and each potted plant does represent a stable system.

C.Choice: The variables are similar, and you can expect the same results in the potted plant and the flower garden without collecting more data.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because the variables are not similar.

D.Choice: The variables are different, so you cannot expect the same results in the potted plant and the flower garden without collecting more data.

Key.Rationale: Even small changes to one part of a system can cause large changes elsewhere, and testing two plants does not provide conclusive evidence to support such a change.

Content: Based on the observations regarding matter and energy flow in the containers, the student describes the role of the earthworm in the ecosystem created in the investigation. Which description ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß explains the role of earthworms in the ecosystem?

A.Choice: consumers, because they eat organisms that would compete with plants for beneficial nutrients

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because only other plants compete with plants for nutrients, and the plants exposed to earthworms were all similar and all flourished.

B.Choice: producers, because they use energy from the Sun to produce nutrients that are needed by plants

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because earthworms are not capable of carrying out photosynthesis.

C.Choice: decomposers, because they break down substances in the soil that provide nutrients for plants

Key.Rationale: The improved growth of plants exposed to earthworms suggests that the plants received additional nutrients. Decomposers enrich soil with materials useful to producers.

D.Choice: scavengers, because they can survive in soils that have very few nutrients and still remain healthy

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because there is no evidence that the potting soil included the decaying biomass needed by scavengers.

Content: Which statement can ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß be supported by Figure 1?

A.Choice: Chickens are more closely related to tortoises than rabbits are.

Key.Rationale: The third row in the progression diagram shows more similarities between the tortoise and the chicken than between the tortoise and the rabbit.

B.Choice: Rabbits, chickens, tortoises, and fish are equally related to each other.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because only the first row in the progression diagram supports this assertion. The third row in the progression diagram shows that differences exist.

C.Choice: Fish do not share a common ancestor with other vertebrates.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because the first row in the progression diagram shows common characteristics, such as gill slits and the presence of a tail, which support common ancestry.

D.Choice: Fish and chickens are the least closely related.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because the third row in the progression diagram shows more differences between the fish and the rabbit than between the fish and the chicken.

Content: Which question can ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß be answered by the data in Figure 1?

A.Choice: How long does it take different organisms to develop into adults?

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because there are no time references in the figure.

B.Choice: Do diverse organisms follow a similar progression of development?

Key.Rationale: Figure 1 shows distinctive similarities and differences in the development progression of diverse organisms.

C.Choice: Do modern organisms follow the same development progression as ancient organisms?

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because there is no reference for differentiating ancient organisms from modern organisms, and the organisms listed could all be considered modern.

D.Choice: Which characteristics at each developmental stage increase an organism's chance of survival?

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because there are no structures presented in the figure that are diverse enough to support the assertion.

Content: Figure 1 shows the relationship between the discovery of new oil reserves and human consumption of oil.
problems/NJG8S/media/13a.jpg
Construct an explanation of the change in oil reserves beyond the year 2000 using the data in Figure 1.
Complete the sentences by choosing the correct answer from each box.
Based on the data in the graph, discoveries of new oil reserves beyond the year 2000 :DD-1: . Oil is a :DD-2: resource, which means the supply replenishes :DD-3: than human demand.

Key.Rationale: Based on the trends in the graph, the number of exploratory drilling sites for oil has been decreasing.

Based on the trends in the graph, the number of exploratory drilling sites for oil has been decreasing. This will lead to an overall decrease in the amount of available oil because oil is a non-renewable resource.
Oil is a non-renewable resource that requires such a long time to produce that its supply can be considered finite.

Content: Students observed the phases of the Moon on two nights during a month. Their observations are shown in Figure 2.
problems/NJG8S/media/14a.jpg
Which statement uses the model in Figure 1 to correctly explain the change that occurred between Observation 1 and Observation 2 in Figure 2?

A.Choice: Earth rotated, so the dark side of the planet was facing Position 3 rather than Position 1.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because it is the Moon's position relative to Earth, not Earth's rotation, that determines the Moon's phase.

B.Choice: Earth rotated, so the dark side of the planet was facing Position 7 rather than Position 1.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because it is the Moon's position relative to Earth, not Earth's rotation, that determines the Moon's phase.

C.Choice: The Moon moved from Position 1 to Position 3, which caused the Sun to shine on parts of the Moon that people on Earth cannot see.

Key.Rationale: The Moon changes positions as it revolves around Earth. The portion of the Moon that is illuminated by the Sun and visible from Earth changes in each position. The Moon appears full during Observation 1, indicating that it is in Position 1. Only the side of the Moon that is closest to the Sun is illuminated by the Sun in Observation 2, indicating that the Moon has moved to Position 3.

D.Choice: The Moon moved from Position 1 to Position 7, which caused Earth to block the sunlight and make the Moon appear dark.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because, in that position, the opposite side of the Moon would be illuminated by the Sun.

Content: Based on the position of the Sun and Earth in Figure 1, determine where the full, new, first-quarter, and third-quarter moons are located in Figure 3.
problems/NJG8S/media/15a.jpg
Complete the diagram by choosing the correct answer from each box.
Box W

A.Choice: new moon

B.Choice: full moon

C.Choice: first-quarter moon

D.Choice: third-quarter moon

Key.Rationale: Half of the Moon's surface is always illuminated by the Sun. The third-quarter moon occurs between the full moon and the new moon.

Content: Box X

A.Choice: new moon

B.Choice: full moon

Key.Rationale: Half of the Moon's surface is always illuminated by the Sun. The full moon occurs when the entire side of the Moon illuminated by the Sun faces Earth.

C.Choice: first-quarter moon

D.Choice: third-quarter moon

Content: Box Y

A.Choice: new moon

B.Choice: full moon

C.Choice: first-quarter moon

Key.Rationale: Half of the Moon's surface is always illuminated by the Sun. The first-quarter moon occurs between the new moon and the full moon.

D.Choice: third-quarter moon

Content: Box Z

A.Choice: new moon

Key.Rationale: Half of the Moon's surface is always illuminated by the Sun. A new moon occurs when the entire side of the Moon illuminated by the Sun faces away from Earth.

B.Choice: full moon

C.Choice: first-quarter moon

D.Choice: third-quarter moon

Content: A student observes the Moon when it is in Position 2 of Figure 1. Help the student create a table that shows the position the Moon will be in after the specified number of days have passed.
:table:problems/NJG8S/supps/NJG8S-T1.json
Complete the table by choosing the correct answer from each box.

Key.Rationale: It takes the Moon a little more than 27 days to revolve around Earth once. That means that every two positions shown in Figure 1 represent a span of about 1 week (27/8 = about 3.5 days per position). From a starting point of Position 2, 8 days (about 1 week) involves moving two positions to Position 4.
Position 8 is about 3 weeks (22 days) from Position 2.
36 days (about 5 weeks) from Position 2 is indicated by Position 4.

Content: Based on the experiment in the passage, select the statement that accurately describes the increase or decrease of the kinetic energy of the particles.

A.Choice: The kinetic energy of the particles will increase in the washers after being placed in the cup of water.

B.Choice: The kinetic energy of the particles will increase in the water that is in the beaker as it is being heated.

Key.Rationale: Thermal energy flows from warmer regions to cooler regions. As the particles within a region gain heat, they begin to move more quickly and gain kinetic energy.

C.Choice: The kinetic energy of the particles will decrease in the washers after being placed in the beaker of water.

D.Choice: The kinetic energy of the particles will remain the same in the water that is in the beaker as it is being heated.

Content: The molecules that make up the different materials in the passage have different kinetic energies.
Select the answer that provides the correct order of the samples from greatest kinetic energy of the molecules at the top of the list to least kinetic energy at the bottom.

A.Choice:
water in the beaker after it comes to a boil
water in the cup after the washer is added
water in the cup before the washer is added

Key.Rationale: The kinetic energy of a given material increases as the speed of the material's individual particles increases, and the hotter a material is, the faster its particles move. Therefore, arranging the options from warmest temperature to coolest temperature orders them by decreasing kinetic energy. Based on the heat transfers that occur during the investigation, the boiling water in the beaker has the greatest amount of kinetic energy, while the water in the cup before the washers are added has the least amount of kinetic energy.

B.Choice:
water in the cup after the washer is added
water in the beaker after it comes to a boil
water in the cup before the washer is added

C.Choice:
water in the cup before the washer is added
water in the beaker after it comes to a boil
water in the cup after the washer is added

D.Choice:
water in the cup after the washer is added
water in the cup before the washer is added
water in the beaker after it comes to a boil

Content: This item has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then answer Part B.
The student used Table 1 to record the temperatures of the washers and of the water in the cup after the washers were placed in the cup. However, the student forgot to label the table.
Select the bar graph that correctly shows the temperatures that represent each material in Table 1.
problems/NJG8S/media/19a.jpg

A.Choice: problems/NJG8S/media/19b.jpg

B.Choice: problems/NJG8S/media/19c.jpg

Key.Rationale: Thermal energy is transferred from warmer objects to cooler objects. In this investigation, the washers are initially much warmer than the water in the cup. Therefore, the data in the first row of the table that show decreasing temperatures over time represent the washers, and the data in the second row that show increasing temperatures represent the water in the cup. Applying these data to the bar graph, the water in the cup should be 22¬∞C at 30 s, 28¬∞C at 60 s, and 32¬∞C at 90 s. The washers should be 96¬∞C at 30 s, 66¬∞C at 60 s, and 46¬∞C at 90 s.

C.Choice: problems/NJG8S/media/19d.jpg

D.Choice: problems/NJG8S/media/19e.jpg

Content: Using the information provided, determine what will happen as the experiment goes longer than 90 seconds.
Complete the sentences by choosing the correct answer from each box.
As the experiment goes longer than 90 seconds, the temperature of the water in the cup will :DD-1: , and the temperature of the washers will :DD-2: . This will continue :DD-3: .

Key.Rationale: Thermal energy will continue to be transferred from the warmer washers to the cooler water in the cup until the temperature of the washers is the same as the temperature of the water in the cup.
Thermal energy will continue to be transferred from the warmer washers to the cooler water in the cup until the temperature of the washers is the same as the temperature of the water in the cup.

3:A.Choice: until the temperatures are the same

Key.Rationale: Thermal energy will continue to be transferred from the warmer washers to the cooler water in the cup until the temperature of the washers is the same as the temperature of the water in the cup.

3:B.Choice: but the temperatures will never be equal

Content: The student repeats the experiment but fills the cup with 60 mL of water instead of 30 mL.

:ibox:‚Ä¢ Predict what will happen in the experiment.

‚Ä¢ Explain why the predicted result would likely occur.
Be sure to discuss the motion of molecules and the transfer of energy.
Figure 1 demonstrates how lighthouses in the 1800s directed bright light toward ships.
Complete the sentence by choosing the correct answer from each box.
In the projection method shown in Figure 1, light waves travel :DD-1: until they :DD-2: the surface of the :DD-3: .

Key.Rationale: All light waves travel in straight lines until they encounter another medium where they are either reflected, absorbed, or transmitted. In Figure 1, the light waves travel in straight lines until they meet the surface of the mirror.
Because the mirror is curved, all the light waves reflect off the surface of the mirror in paths that are parallel to one another.
Because the mirror is curved, all the light waves reflect off the surface of the mirror in paths that are parallel to one another.

Content: Figure 2 shows one model of light projection.
The answer to which question ùó†ùó¢ùó¶ùóß ùóîùóñùóñùó®ùó•ùóîùóßùóòùóüùó¨ clarifies the role of the lens in Figure 2?

A.Choice: Does the lens transmit or reflect light waves?

Key.Rationale: Figure 2 shows that the light waves that reach the lens pass through the lens, so the light waves are transmitted through the lens and not reflected by the lens.

B.Choice: Does the lens change the color of the light waves?

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because the lens does not affect the color of the light waves.

C.Choice: How far out at sea can light waves be seen using lenses?

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because the lens does not affect the distance the light waves travel.

D.Choice: How does the lens transfer matter from one side to the other?

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because the lens does not actively transfer matter from one side to the other.

Content: Foghorns are another method of warning ships that they are close to the shore. Foghorns emit low- pitched sound waves in all directions that can be heard on ships when visibility is low. Low- pitched waves have longer wavelengths that are less likely to be blocked by barriers such as rocks.
Compare the warning signals emitted by a lighthouse with those emitted by a foghorn.
Select all the correct answers. You may select more than one answer for each scenario.

A:Lighthouse:2.Choice: 2:The signal system is designed to focus the wave in a specific direction.

Key.Rationale: Figure 1 and Figure 2 show that the signal system used by lighthouses is designed to focus light waves in a specific direction. However, sound waves are emitted by the foghorn in all directions.
Light is a form of energy.

B:Foghorn:1.Choice: 1:The signal is transmitted by compression and expansion of air particles.

Key.Rationale: Light waves consist of electromagnetic radiation and do not require a medium through which to travel. The foghorn uses sound waves that require a medium through which to travel. In this case, the sound waves are transmitted by the compression and expansion of air particles.
The signal system used by a foghorn emits sound, which is a form of energy.

Content: Which question can ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß be answered by analyzing the data in Figure 1?

A.Choice: Why are bats not attracted by green light?

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because the data in Figure 1 show that green light affects bat activity but do not explain why this happens.

B.Choice: Can bats distinguish a green grasshopper from a red ant at night?

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because Figure 1 shows data on the number of times bats passed by different colored lights and does not include data on how bats can distinguish green and red insects.

C.Choice: Are bats likely to be affected by green lights and red lights shining together?

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because the data in Figure 1 do not provide information about how the combination of green and red light affects bat activity.

D.Choice: What color light should be used to observe bat activity without affecting their behavior?

Key.Rationale: The data show that, of the colors tested, red light has the least effect on the bats' behavior compared with when no artificial light is present.

Content: Identify the independent variable in this investigation and the body system that would be ùó†ùó¢ùó¶ùóß affected by this factor.
Complete the sentences by choosing the correct answer from each box.
The independent variable in this investigation is the :DD-1: . The investigation provided evidence that the bats‚Ä≤ :DD-2: is reacting to a stimulus and affecting the behavior of the bats.

Key.Rationale: The independent variable is the color of light, which the researchers manipulate and is indicated on the x-axis of Figure 1.
Light acts as a stimulus to the bats' nervous system, which coordinates the behavioral response of the bats to the light.

Content: Which statement ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß compares the claims of the two students?

A.Choice: Student 2‚Ä≤s claim explains how ears send information to the brain, and Student 1‚Ä≤s claim explains how the brain sends messages to the muscles for immediate action.

Key.Rationale: Student 1's claim explains how the nervous system coordinates a response to a stimulus by sending messages to the muscular system. Student 2's claim explains how a bat's ears sense sounds and send this information to the brain.

B.Choice: Student 2‚Ä≤s claim explains how the brain is not needed to process information, and Student 1‚Ä≤s claim explains how muscle memory is used to capture prey.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because the brain is needed to process information about sounds and muscle memory does not occur when the nervous system sends messages to the muscles for immediate action.

C.Choice: Student 1‚Ä≤s claim explains how the brain stores memories, and Student 2‚Ä≤s claim explains how these memories are used to locate prey.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because neither students' claim explains how the brain stores memories nor how memories may be useful in locating prey.

D.Choice: Student 1‚Ä≤s claim explains how the brain reacts to sounds, and Student 2‚Ä≤s claim explains how these sounds are stored as memories.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because Student 1's claim does not discuss the role of sounds and Student 2's claim does not explain the storage of memories.

Content: A city council proposes adding light fixtures that produce white light to roads and parking lots in one area of a community. A student claims that the action will result in an increase in the population of insects in the area. Which scientific reasoning ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß supports the student‚Ä≤s claim?

A.Choice: Bats will be more visible in white light, allowing insects to evade them.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because the study did not investigate the effect of light on the activity of insects.

B.Choice: Insects will be likely to hide from white light, preventing bats from preying on them.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because the study did not investigate the effect of light on the activity of insects.

C.Choice: Bats will travel to different areas to avoid the white lights, so the bats will eat fewer insects in the area.

Key.Rationale: Figure 1 shows that white light decreased the number of times bats passed by. Since bats will avoid the white light, the bats will eat fewer insects in the area with light. So, the number of insects will increase in the area with white light.

D.Choice: Larger prey will be more visible in the white lights than insects will, which will lead bats to change their diet.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because the study did not investigate the effect of light on the ability of bats to see different sizes of prey.

Content: Based on Figure 1, which data is the student trying to produce by conducting the investigation?

A.Choice: the components that produce rust

Key.Rationale: Figure 1 shows an investigation with metal exposed to different conditions. Since the metal only rusts when certain conditions/components are present, the investigation is trying to identify what components produce rust.

B.Choice: the types of metal that rust the fastest

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because the investigation did not test different types of metals.

C.Choice: the amount of rust that forms every 10 days

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because the investigation did not measure the amount of rust in 10 day increments, simply the presence and relative amount of rust after 10 days under different conditions.

D.Choice: the amount of mass lost during the rusting process

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because the investigation did not measure changes in mass across the samples.

Content: Based on Figure 1, identify which test tubes show evidence of a chemical reaction.
Complete the sentence by choosing the correct answer from each box.
Evidence of a chemical reaction is shown in :DD-1: because the iron pieces :DD-2: .

Key.Rationale: The formation of rust is a chemical reaction since the molecules reorganize to form a new substance, which is shown in only test tubes 1 and 4.
The formation of rust is a chemical reaction since the molecules reorganize to form a new substance.

Content: The elements Iron (Fe) and Oxygen (O) are found in a molecule of rust. Based on Figure 1, describe the atoms and molecules in the reactants and product of the rust reaction.
Complete the sentences by choosing the correct answer from each box.

The types of atoms found in the reactants and products are :DD-1: . During the reaction, the atoms form :DD-2: molecules. The number of atoms in the reactants will be :DD-3: the number of atoms in the product.

Key.Rationale: When a chemical reaction takes place, different molecules are formed due to the rearrangement of atoms. Since matter is conserved when a chemical reaction occurs, the same number and types of atoms should be present in both the reactants and the products.

When a chemical reaction takes place, different molecules are formed due to the rearrangement of atoms. Since matter is conserved when a chemical reaction occurs, the same number and types of atoms should be present in both the reactants and the products.

When a chemical reaction takes place, different molecules are formed due to the rearrangement of atoms. Since matter is conserved when a chemical reaction occurs, the same number and types of atoms should be present in both the reactants and the products.

Content: Two groups of students made claims about why the iron parts of a bicycle would rust when left outdoors near the ocean. Based on Figure 1, identify which student group was correct for each claim.
Select one option for each claim.
Claim A

A.Choice: Group 1: A bicycle will rust only when the air is salty.

B.Choice: Group 2: A bicycle will rust more quickly when the air is salty.

Key.Rationale: Rust is created when iron is exposed to oxygen and moisture. For claim A, only oxygen and water are required to form rust, as shown by test tube 1. When salt is present, the formation of rust is sped up, but it is not a requirement.

Content: Claim B

A.Choice: Group 1: A bicycle will rust outdoors because water and oxygen are in the atmosphere.

Key.Rationale: Rust is created when iron is exposed to oxygen and moisture. For claim B, if only oxygen is present, the chemical reaction that produces rust will not occur and rust will not form. Water must be present for rust to form, as seen by the fact that test tube 2 does not show any rust.

B.Choice: Group 2: A bicycle will rust outdoors because only oxygen is in the atmosphere.

Content: Based on Table 1, identify the properties that provide evidence that iron and rust are not the same substance.

Key.Rationale: Since iron and rust are solids at room temperature, their physical state at room temperature does not provide evidence that iron and rust are not the same substance.

The density of a substance is dependent upon the atoms that make up the substance, therefore if two substances with the same phase have different densities then they are made of different atoms, which makes them different substances. Therefore, since the density of iron is different from the density of rust, this is evidence that they are different substances.
The mass of a substance does not provide evidence that a substance is not the same as another substance, it just shows that one sample is smaller than the other.

The melting point of a substance is dependent upon the strength of the bonds between the atoms in the substance, therefore if their melting points are different then they are different substances. Since iron and rust have different melting points, this is evidence that they are different substances.

Content: This item has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then answer Part B.

Scientists also studied a population of diamondback terrapins that live in Oyster Bay, about forty miles north of Jamaica Bay. Table 1 lists the items in the terrapins‚Ä≤ diet in approximately one month.
problems/NJG8S/media/33a.jpg
Based on Figure 2 and Table 1, what is the difference between the percentage of algae in the diet of Jamaica Bay terrapins and the percentage of algae in the diet of Oyster Bay terrapins?

Key.Rationale: From Table 1, the percentage of algae in the diet of terrapins in Oyster Bay is 20% (24/120 x 100%). From Figure 2, the percentage of algae in the diet of terrapins in Jamaica Bay is 39%. Therefore, the difference is 19% (39% - 20%).

Content: What conclusion about the two ecosystems can be drawn based on this information?
Complete the sentences by choosing the correct answer from each box.

The percentage of algae in the diet of Oyster Bay terrapins is :DD-1: than the percentage of algae in the diet of Jamaica Bay terrapins. This suggests that the Oyster Bay ecosystem :DD-2: than the Jamaica Bay ecosystem.

Key.Rationale: The percentage of algae in the diet of Oyster Bay terrapins is less than the percentage of algae in the diet of Jamaica Bay terrapins.

Algae is lower in protein and difficult for the terrapins to digest. Since there is less algae present in the diet of Oyster Bay terrapins, this suggests that the Oyster Bay ecosystem is healthier for terrapins than the Jamaica Bay ecosystem.

Content: Which statement ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß explains why the number of terrapin nests decreased in Jamaica Bay?

A.Choice: The algae reduced the amount of sunlight that reaches terrapins, so the terrapins have less energy for reproduction.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because terrapins are consumers and not producers.

B.Choice: The increased proportion of algae in the terrapins‚Ä≤ diet does not provide as much of the nutrients needed for reproduction.

Key.Rationale: Terrapins require nutrients to reproduce. The data show that algae makeup 39% of the diet of diamondback terrapins in Jamaica Bay. Algae is lower in protein and difficult for the terrapins to digest. Therefore, the increased proportion of algae in the terrapins' diet does not provide as much of the nutrients needed for the terrapins to reproduce.

C.Choice: Decreased amounts of nutrients in the ecosystem have meant that there are fewer female terrapins to carry out reproduction.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because the number of female terrapins in the research study remained the same.

D.Choice: Reproduction remained the same, but the increased presence of algae caused the terrapins to move their nests to the marshland.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because there was a 50% drop in the number of nests (indicating that the rate of reproduction decreased) and the amount of marshland decreased.

Content: Figure 3 shows a partial food web for Jamaica Bay.
problems/NJG8S/media/35a.jpg
Which statements ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß predict the effects on the Jamaica Bay food web if nothing is done to stop pollution from entering the Jamaica Bay ecosystem?
Select ùóßùó™ùó¢ of the five statements.

A.Choice: Raccoons will become extinct.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because a change in the ecosystem may cause raccoons to leave the ecosystem but will not make the raccoons go extinct.

B.Choice: Clam and crab populations will need to find other food sources.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because an increase in algae will increase the resources available for clams and crabs.

C.Choice: The snail population will increase due to more available resources.

Key.Rationale: An increase in algae will provide more nutrients to snails for reproduction.

D.Choice: The terrapin population will decrease due to a lack of appropriate resources.

Key.Rationale: An increase in algae will provide fewer nutrients that the terrapins need to reproduce.

E.Choice: The diversity of aquatic plants will increase due to a change in the health of the ecosystem.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because the ecosystem is not as healthy due to excess algae, which tends to decrease the diversity of organisms in the ecosystem.

Content: Researchers suggest introducing a non- native algae consumer to the Jamaica Bay ecosystem. Which statements represent benefits associated with the introduction of this non- native species?
Select ùóßùóõùó•ùóòùóò of the five statements.

A.Choice: The new consumer will eat the same prey as terrapins.

Key.Rationale: The new consumer and terrapins both eat algae. This is a concern because the terrapins will have to compete with the new consumer for resources.

B.Choice: The new consumer will attract new predators to the ecosystem.

Key.Rationale: The new consumer will attract new predators to the ecosystem. This is a concern because these predators may also harm organisms that are native to the Jamaica Bay ecosystem.

C.Choice: The new consumer will reduce the amount of algae in Jamaica Bay.

Key.Rationale: The introduction of a non-native algae consumer should help decrease the number of algae present in the Jamaica Bay ecosystem. This is a benefit because increased amounts of algae are linked to a decrease in terrapin reproduction.

D.Choice: The new consumer will force terrapins to eat more clams, crabs, plants, and snails.

Key.Rationale: The new consumer will compete with terrapins for algae as a food source. This is a benefit because it will force the terrapins to eat more clams, crabs, plants, and snails, which have more of the nutrients the terrapins need.

E.Choice: The new consumer will improve water clarity and allow aquatic plants to receive more sunlight.

Key.Rationale: A reduction in the number of algae should improve water clarity. This is a benefit because aquatic plants will be exposed to more sunlight and, as producers, be able to provide more energy for the consumers.

Content: Identify the type of data shown in Figure 2 and predict when the amount of weathering and erosion at DEWA would be expected to be the highest.
Complete the sentences by choosing the correct answer from each box.

The data shown in Figure 2 are an example of :DD-1: data. The amount of weathering and erosion at DEWA would be expected to be highest in :DD-2: . This is because precipitation causes :DD-3: in the rate of weathering and erosion.

Key.Rationale: The data in figure 2 are data that can be measured and are quantitative.
Weathering and erosion increase when precipitation increases, so the weathering and erosion will be greatest in May/June.
Weathering and erosion increase when precipitation increases.

Content: Use Figure 3 to describe the water cycle.
Complete the sentences by choosing the correct answer from each box.

Figure 3 shows that, at sea level, where air temperatures are the highest, :DD-1: of water occurs. Figure 3 also shows that freezing temperatures can cause :DD-2: , which with gravity, often leads to water falling to the ground as solid precipitation. Then as :DD-3: , the water moves across the surface, eventually flowing into the lake and the ocean.

Key.Rationale: When temperatures are high, water will change from the liquid state to the gaseous state, so evaporation will occur.
Freezing temperatures cause water to change from the gaseous state to the solid state, so crystallization will occur.
Once the water falls to the ground, it will move as runoff and flow to lakes and oceans.

Content: Table 1 shows the percentages of the minerals quartz and gypsum in samples from five collection sites. Site 1 is north of the DEWA. Sites 2‚Äì5 are south of the DEWA, with Sites 4 and 5 being located near the city of Trenton.
problems/NJG8S/media/39a.jpg

Based on this information, the student claims that the results of erosion caused by the Delaware River will be greatest near Trenton. Which ùóßùó™ùó¢ pieces of evidence best support the student‚Ä≤s claim?
Select ùóßùó™ùó¢ of the five statements.

A.Choice: Sites 1‚Äì 3 had lower percentages of gypsum than of quartz.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because comparing data from sites 1-3 does not support the student's explanation.

B.Choice: Trenton is closer to the Delaware Water Gap than the other sites.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because Trenton's position is not close to the gap and the other sites upstream must be closer.

C.Choice: Trenton is a larger city than the other sites, which may cause a greater amount of erosion.

Key.Rationale: This option is invalid because physical erosion along the Delaware River is not a function of the size of a nearby city.

D.Choice: The data show higher percentages of gypsum and quartz the closer the samples are to Trenton.

Key.Rationale: Table 1 shows that gypsum and quartz sediment levels are higher in Trenton.

E.Choice: Trenton lies downstream of the DEWA, where sediments from erosion may exist in greater amounts.

Key.Rationale: Table 1 shows that a location's position downstream indicates a higher level of physical erosion.

Content: Scientists collected erosion and weathering data from three collection sites in the Delaware River. The average of the total suspended rock and soil sediments is a measure of erosion, and the total dissolved solids is a measure of weathering. The data are shown in Table 2.
problems/NJG8S/media/40a.jpg
Use Figure 1 to explain the data shown in Table 2. In your response, be sure to do the following:

:ibox:‚Ä¢ describe the trend in the data shown in Table 2.

‚Ä¢ explain one factor that could be the cause of the trend in the data.
Use Figure 1 to explain the data shown in Table 2. In your response, be sure to do the following:

:ibox:‚Ä¢ identify what information is needed to determine if this factor explains the trend in the data.

‚Ä¢ explain how this information would be interpreted.
